user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of check_apply_params:
```c
static int
check_apply_params (void)
{
  if (tool_params.help)
  {
    show_help ();
    return -1;
  }
  else if (tool_params.version)
  {
    print_version ();
    return -1;
  }
  check_param_port ();
  check_apply_param__all_cpus ();
  check_apply_param__threads ();
  if (! check_apply_param__thread_per_conn ())
    return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
  if (! check_param__epoll ())
    return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
  if (! check_param__poll ())
    return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
  check_param__empty_tiny_medium_large ();
  check_param__shared_single_unique ();
  if (! check_param__connections ())
    return PERF_RPL_ERR_CODE_BAD_PARAM;
  return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragment in the supplied function is statically unreachable. Each statement can be executed depending on runtime conditions: the initial if/else-if branches both return only when their respective conditions are true (the else-if is reachable when tool_params.help is false), the intermediate returns depend on the boolean results of the various check_...() calls, and the final return 0 is reachable when none of the checks trigger an earlier return. There are no statements placed after an unconditional return in the same block, no infinite loops that block following code, and no compile-time-constant conditions that make any branch impossible to reach based on the provided snippet. Determination of any additional unreachable code would require further context (e.g. definitions of tool_params or the check_...() functions), but based solely on this code fragment there are no violations of Rule 2.1 to flag.
